question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
The matrix for projecting onto a certain line $\ell,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{50} & \frac{7}{50} \\ \frac{7}{50} & \frac{49}{50} \end{pmatrix}.\]Find the direction vector of line $\ell.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ and $b$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|) = 1.$
inference:
The direction vector of line $\ell$ is the eigenvector of the projection matrix corresponding to the eigenvalue $1.$  The characteristic polynomial of the matrix is
\[\begin{align*}
p(\lambda) &= \det\begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{50}-\lambda & \frac{7}{50} \\ \frac{7}{50} & \frac{49}{50}-\lambda \end{pmatrix}\\
&= \left(\frac{1}{50}-\lambda\right)\left(\frac{49}{50}-\lambda\right)-\frac{49}{2500}\\
&= \frac{1}{2500}-\frac{50}{2500}\lambda+\lambda^2-\frac{49}{2500}\\
&= \lambda^2-\frac{50}{2500}\lambda+\frac{1}{2500}\\
&= \left(\lambda-\frac{1}{50}\right)\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{50}\right)\\
&= (\lambda-1/50)^2.
\end{align*}\]

So, the only eigenvalue is $\lambda = 1/50,$ and the corresponding eigenspace is
\[\begin{align*}
\text{Eig}\left(\frac{1}{50}\right) &= \left\{\mathbf{v} \in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid \begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{50}-\frac{1}{50} & \frac{7}{50} \\ \frac{7}{50} & \frac{49}{50}-\frac{1}{50} \end{pmatrix}\mathbf{v} = \mathbf{0} \right\}\\
&= \left\{\mathbf{v} \in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid \begin{pmatrix} 0 & \frac{7}{50} \\ \frac{7}{50} & \frac{48}{50} \end{pmatrix}\mathbf{v} = \mathbf{0} \right\}\\
&= \left\{\mathbf{v} \in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid \frac{7}{50}v_2 = 0 \right\}\\
&= \left\{\mathbf{v} \in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid v_2 = 0 \right\}\\
&= \text{span}\left\{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\right\}.
\end{align*}\]

Therefore, the direction vector of line $\ell$ is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.$
Final Answer: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Let $\mathbf{P}$ denote the given matrix, so $\mathbf{P} \mathbf{v}$ is the projection of $\mathbf{v}$ onto $\ell.$  In particular, $\mathbf{P} \mathbf{v}$ lies on $\ell$ for any vector $\mathbf{v}.$  So, we can take $\mathbf{v} = \mathbf{i}.$  Then
\[\mathbf{P} \mathbf{i} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{50} \\ \frac{7}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the direction vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}.$

p(\lambda) &= \det\begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{50}-\lambda & \frac{7}{50} \\ \frac{7}{50} & \frac{49}{50}-\lambda \end{pmatrix}\\

&= \frac{1}{2500}-\frac{50}{2500}\lambda+\lambda^2-\frac{49}{2500}\\
&= \lambda^2-\frac{50}{2500}\lambda+\frac{1}{2500}\\
&= \left(\lambda-\frac{1}{50}\right)\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{50}\right)\\

&= \left\{\mathbf{v} \in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid \begin{pmatrix} 0 & \frac{7}{50} \\ \frac{7}{50} & \frac{48}{50} \end{pmatrix}\mathbf{v} = \mathbf{0} \right\}\\
&= \left\{\mathbf{v} \in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid \frac{7}{50}v_2 = 0 \right\}\\
&= \left\{\mathbf{v} \in \mathbb{R}^2 \mid v_2 = 0 \right\}\\
&= \text{span}\left\{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\right\}.

Therefore, the direction vector of line $\ell$ is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.$
